1.brief: perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
near, with or among; often in general, to

a trumpet (from its sundered or quavering note)
silver (from its pale color); by implication, money
rounded work, i.e. moulded by hammering (repousse)

properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
something called out, i.e. a public meeting (the act, the persons, or the place); also a rehearsal
a stated assemblage (specifically, a concourse, or generally, a family or crowd)
a departure (from striking the tents), i.e. march (not necessarily a single day's travel); by implication, a station (or point of departure)

an encampment (of travellers or troops); hence, an army, whether literal (of soldiers) or figurative (of dancers, angels, cattle, locusts, stars; or even the sacred courts)

properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first

near, with or among; often in general, to
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
near, with or among; often in general, to
nativity (plural birth-place); by implication, lineage, native country; also offspring, family
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)

'I pray', 'now', or 'then'; added mostly to verbs (in the Imperative or Future), or to interjections, occasionally to an adverb or conjunction
to loosen, i.e. relinquish, permit, etc.
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
properly, to incline; by implication, to decline (of the slanting rays of evening); specifically, to pitch atent; gen. to encamp (for abode or siege)
a pasture (i.e. open field, whither cattle are driven); by implication, a desert; also speech (including its organs)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
to be (causative) make well, literally (sound, beautiful) or figuratively (happy, successful, right)
